text: [Music]
hi everybody thank you so much for
having me at the summit it's a pleasure
to speak with you all today
i'm a cardiologist at mayo clinic so i'm
going to be coming at
my presentation from a bit of a
different perspective than many of the
other speakers
i take care of patients with cardiac
disease and i run our ecg and
physiologic monitoring lab
which handles essentially all the
clinical data that's time series data
around physiologic heart monitoring and
so forth
and we have been archiving our data at
mayo
clinic for several decades now and we've
realized that we've been sitting on
top of essentially a treasure trove of
high quality consistent well-labeled
data
and some of my colleagues had the
insight that if we could
work with some data scientists we could
really unlock a lot of
information that's essentially hidden in
plain sight in this ecg data
and i'd like to tell you essentially the
story of how we've been doing that over
the past couple of years
so the title of my talk is how smart is
the ecg and i think you'll see that it's
smarter than we thought
and i'll teach you some lessons from
advanced ecg analytics
the work that i'll present is funded by
various sources including nih and
benefactor funds and some of the
technology that i'll talk
about today has been disclosed or
patented by mayo clinic and we're in the
process of trying to
bring this to market in various
fashions so first of all what does the
future of ecg
interpretation look like the ecg is
really one of the most well established
and
oldest parts of cardiology it's the
electrical recording of heart activity
and it hasn't really changed much at all
in about 100 years
but what we're seeing is that by
applying some of these technologies to
the ecg data
we're really learning a lot more from
this relatively humble
modality and let me just give you a case
example to illustrate this this was a 35
year old man
who presented after his sister had died
suddenly
and he underwent an ecg he was worried
about his heart and it was actually read
by our cardiology team as a normal ecg
and it was
essentially uninformative this looks
normal but when we took some of the
models that we developed over the past
couple of years
it actually demonstrated that it thought
that he had poor heart function
and that his heart muscle was weak gave
him a 76 probability
of having a low ejection fraction and
then we went on to do the gold standard
test which is an echocardiogram or a
sonogram
it in fact confirmed that his heart
function was very poor
and he went on to be diagnosed with a
familial cardiomyopathy
which probably explained his sister's
death and then other people in his
family were screened and this is an
example
how new technology applied to an old
modality
can yield new insights at the point of
care and make a big difference
in uh patients lives so taking a step
back
when we think about applying ai
technologies to ec interpret
ecg interpretation there's two basic
goals that we're trying to reach
one is to streamline human capability
can a computer read an ecg as well as a
human
and if we're able to accomplish that
then we can do better first pass
interpretations we can triage ecgs based
on the likelihood of
abnormalities and we can scale the work
that we do at mayo clinic we read about
400 000 ecgs a year
but that takes an army of technologists
and cardiologists to do so
and if we could leverage ai we could do
that more effectively
at lower cost and at scale that's kind
of the obvious
application of ai to the ecg but the
more interesting one
in my opinion is actually to go beyond
human capability and these are the kinds
of things
where an uh ml algorithm or ai
trained on ecg data can actually see
beyond
what a cardiologist can see and in that
sense it's adding new value to the ecg
and it moves beyond this ecg as normal
this one is abnormal
to something that is much more richly
informative so if we talk
first about doing what we do
on the cardiology side scaling human
capability
we're essentially asking whether our
technologies
can pass the turing test can a
cardiologist look at a
read that is done by the ai and tell it
from the read that is done by an expert
cardiologist
and we just recently completed this
study where we used standard
ecg interpretation software our ai
algorithms
and then the ecg lab read which is a
combination of our technologists
and our cardiologists to read it and
essentially we've asked expert
cardiologists to
say which of these reads was correct in
a blinded fashion
and what we're finding is that our ai
can get it right about 94 percent of the
time
and it gets all of the codes right on an
ecg about 85 percent of the
time so this is better than the
state-of-the-art analog
kind of ecg software but it's still not
up to the point where we can rely
completely on these technologies we
still require some human oversight
and this is something we're going to
continue to work on and refine
but i think the more interesting
examples that i'd like to show today
are where we can see beyond human
capabilities on the ecg and i'll give
you
three examples the first example
is the example that i showed in the
opening slide about detection of low
ejection fraction
or a weak heart muscle the ecg is
basically designed to tell us about
heart rhythm what's the heart rate what
what is the nature of the rhythm what
kind of abnormalities are there
but it's not a test that tells us much
at least we didn't think
about heart function but by taking a
large data set at mayo clinic
of people who had paired ecg data and
echocardiography data the echo is what
tells us about heart function
we could train a convolutional neural
network to pick up the
signature on a normal 12-lead ecg that
correlate well with abnormalities of
heart function by echocardio
echocardiography and it took about a
hundred thousand ecgs to train
but a very rich data set we could do
that and we can see very good test
performance both in the validation and
testing data sets
and we achieved an area under the
receiver operator curve of 0.93
which in medicine is very good
in other tests that we use all the time
in routine clinical practice maybe a pap
smear or a mammogram
or psa testing for prostate cancer
typically have
auc's in the range of 0.7 to about .85
or so so
in fact this test does better than many
things that we've accepted
the next step of course is to validate
the algorithm in external populations
and we've done that
from populations around the world and
we're currently validating it
in other u.s populations because of
course the achilles heel of many of
these algorithms is that they work very
well
in a particular data set they may work
well at mayo clinic but it might not
generalize well
to other populations and that's the next
thing that we're trying to evaluate
we've made these algorithms readily
available to clinicians at mayo clinic
and
groups from around our practice have
started to apply and test them in
various modalities
so it's been tested in the emergency
department for people who come into the
emergency room
short of breath and in that group it
performs very well so it's probably a
good test
for telling somebody who's come in with
an emergency they're short of breath
whether they have asthma or whether they
have heart failure or whether they have
pneumonia or what
what's the likely cause of their
shortness of breath
and it performs better than routine
blood tests for that
our colleagues in the cardiac critical
care unit have looked at it
for detection of low ejection fraction
and people who are hospitalized with
severe cardiac disease and it performs
well in that situation and even more so
it actually correlates well with
hospital mortality so it's not only
diagnostically important but it's also
potential
it carries potential prognostic value
we have to be cognizant of the risk of
perpetuating or
creating bias in medicine and a
algorithm that is trained predominantly
in
a caucasian population for instance may
not generalize well
across other demographics racial or
ethnic subgroups
so we've performed analyses looking at
various racial and ethnic
subgroups and the auc is remarkably
consistent for this algorithm
so we're really starting to get a lot of
confidence that this algorithm can work
well
and that it may be broadly applicable
if we take a step back just for a moment
and go on a bit of a detour the
algorithm performance was
excellent and we thought well perhaps we
could improve the model further by just
adding a few simple demographics what if
we added
age and sex to the model could we go
from 0.93
to 0.99 and the answer was no and in
fact
it didn't improve model performance at
all which
for me and the other clinicians working
in this field was a bit of a head
scratcher but our data scientists said
well that's not surprising because it's
it's likely that the
convolutional neural network already
knows what it needs
about age and sex just from the ecg so
giving it
structured data about age and sex
probably is not perf
in increasing model performance and
indeed we were able to then demonstrate
that a separate convolutional neural
network was exceptionally good at
determining the sex of the patient by
the ecg
something that most clinicians would not
be able to do and was able to
estimate the age of the patient within
about seven years across a broad range
of
ages so we don't think
of the ecg is telling us much about age
or sex but this is
i think proof that there's there's
something in the ecg that we don't see
that a model like this can see and could
be informative
and that's led to all kinds of
interesting questions if it's
telling us something about age is it
telling us something about physiologic
age does it tell us about frailty does
it tell us about risk of mortality and
so forth
and if it can tell us about sex does it
tell us something about hormonal status
or something so we're
doing a lot of work to try to unpack
that and learn more about it
we found some interesting cases where
there were
patients who didn't seem to fit this
patient was a lot older than his stated
age at the age of about 30 he looked
like he was about 55
he got older year by year and then
dramatically and almost overnight
he seemed to get much younger and when
we dug into this chart we actually found
that he got a heart transplant on that
day and indeed got a heart
of a younger man and that explained the
change in that model output
so it fascinating to me that the model
could pick up that he had received a new
heart
anecdotal but kind of fun the second
example i'll give you is hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy and for those of you who
don't know about this condition this is
the reason
why you'll sometimes hear a dramatic
story about a basketball player
who collapses on the on the court or a
soccer player
and this is a cause of sudden cardiac
death and it can be particularly
problematic in young people and in
athletes because some of the arrhythmias
are associated with exercise
the trouble with this disease is that
while it often results in an abnormal
ecg
the ecg can be abnormal in many
different ways
and the problem is a problem of
increased thickness of the heart muscle
so the voltages get high and there are
all sorts of different abnormalities
but most cardiologists can't look at the
ecg and say with certainty
that this is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
and this is not and because of that
the recommendations for screening for
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with ecg
are somewhat inconsistent
we have a large referral population at
mayo clinic of patients with
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
and we created a paired database of
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy patients and
age and sex match controls
and just like the first example trained
a separate convolutional neural network
to pick up the ecg signature of
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
and this model performed even better
than the low ejection fraction model
with auc's in the range of 0.96
also you see that there's very good
separation of model output
based on low or high outputs based on
the cases and controls
so it really comes down quite
definitively
in favor of or against the diagnosis of
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
the model performed very quite well
across a wide range of subgroups and
particularly well in young patients
which is reassuring to us because those
are the patients we want to actually
screen for
and it performed well whether or not the
ecg was normal or abnormal so some
patients with hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy
have a relatively normal ecg and it
still worked in that
population shortly after we
developed this model we i was rotating
on the clinical service and i was seeing
a young woman
who had was admitted for surgery for
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy so a surgeon
was actually going to take out some of
that
thickened muscle because it was
essentially choking out her heart
and impairing her heart function when i
looked at her ecg it did not look all
that dramatic
in fact the ecg lab called this as a
normal ecg but when we
turned our ai model to this it actually
gave her a 72
probability of having this rare disease
which is a diagnostic odds ratio of
you know several hundred fold the next
day when i rounded on her after her
surgery
i was fascinated to see that even though
now after her surgery her ecg looked
more
abnormal to the model it looked less
like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
so removing that abnormal heart muscle
actually made it look
abnormal but less patho mnemonic of
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
another anecdotal but powerful example
the next example i'll give is atrial
fibrillation and this is a
problem where the heart rate goes often
fast and
irregular the problem with the disease
however is that it's often fleeting and
patients may have this lasting for only
minutes or hours
they may not feel it and by the time
they come in to get it checked out
they're often back in normal rhythm
so the diagnosis can be very elusive and
atrial fibrillation
increases the risk of stroke probably
about five-fold so it's a diagnosis that
is very important to make
but can be very challenging in people
who we think
might have atrial fibrillation for
instance people who have had a stroke
that we can't explain we sometimes go as
far as implanting
a device under the skin that monitors
the heart for about three years looking
for the diagnosis
and that can be expensive and it's
somewhat invasive and it carries some
modest risks so if we could pick up
a signal of atrial fibrillation risk on
the ecg
it could be very powerful and that's
exactly what we did we created a data
set
of patients who had both atrial
fibrillation and sinus rhythm and a data
set of people who had only sinus rhythm
and we trained the model
to pick up the signature of atrial
fibrillation that was
present in the normal sinus rhythm ecg
so even when afib wasn't present it
could still pick up a propensity towards
atrial fibrillation
here the auc is about 0.87 we then took
this model and provid
and applied it to a large data set at
mayo clinic the mayo clinic study of
aging and this is a
group of patients who are very well
characterized over more than a decade
and we have well adjudicated atrial
fibrillation
events in this group and the model
performed well in terms of predicting
the likelihood that these patients go on
to develop atrial fibrillation
and even more so if the model output was
very high
they were actually at higher risk of
stroke so not only
are we predicting the arrhythmia we're
predicting the consequences of the
arrhythmia the actual stroke
shortly after we developed this model
one of our neurologists came to us and
said
would it have been useful for this
patient who has been plaguing me
for the past 12 years or so this was a
woman who had been followed at mayo
clinic for a long time
and she suffered a stroke in 2014
at that time she was in normal sinus
rhythm but this is the model output
for likelihood of atrial fibrillation
and you can see that the model output
was very high this
the threshold for a positive test
even though this patient was in had a
stroke at this time they were in normal
rhythm
and the neurologist couldn't justify
starting an anticoagulant
a few years later she came back
unfortunately with her second stroke
and she was still in normal sinus rhythm
and he had very high
suspicion of atrial fibrillation but
couldn't diagnose it
and it wasn't until a few months later
that she came back with atrial
fibrillation
so the question there was could we have
picked up afib earlier should we have
been screening her before
her first stroke should we have been
treating her empirically with a blood
thinner at the time of her second stroke
and these are the kinds of questions
we'd like to go on to answer
prospectively
so not too long ago nature medicine
editorial board came up with a
editorial on the need for randomized and
prospective clinical trials evaluating
these kinds of ai technologies
and they really believe and we believe
that these kinds of technologies need to
be
held to the same standard as all other
diagnostic and therapeutic interventions
that we that we use in routine clinical
practice
so the next stage is not just to develop
the algorithm but to find ways to test
test it prospectively so just two weeks
ago or may have just been last week we
published
our first clinical trial for this and we
published it in nature medicine the
trial was called the eagle
trial which is ecg guided detection of
low ejection fraction
and essentially what we did was we made
this algorithm available to primary care
physicians
at mayo clinic and we deployed it across
the upper midwest health system
which included about 40 different
clinics and hospital-based
practices across the upper midwest in
wisconsin and iowa
and minnesota and care is generally
delivered by care teams so groups of
doctors working together
and we essentially turn the report the
ai report
on through our electronic tronic health
mecha record
for these care teams in a randomized
fashion so half of the care teams got
the report
half of them didn't and over a
relatively short time we performed the
ai algorithm
on over 32 000 patients and then we
reported in a randomized way
uh whether the report whether the ai
result was positive or negative
and then we suggested that uh clinicians
obtain an echocardiogram or the gold
standard test for low ejection fraction
if the test was positive
what you can see here is that the um
the study was performed in a wide
variety of clinical settings including
mostly
rural patients so these were not
patients being seen
in sub-specialty cardiology clinics or
they were not being taken care of by
doctors who were
enthusiasts or early adopters of ai
technologies this is real world practice
across our health system and most of the
patients were in the outpatient clinic
our primary finding was that the
intervention increased the diagnosis of
previously unrecognized low ejection
fraction
with an odds ratio of 1.32 so we
diagnosed about 30 percent more patients
in routine practice with undiagnosed low
ejection fraction that's a condition
that can progress to heart failure and
can be very important to diagnose
and these are patients that are probably
slipping through the cracks of our
everyday practice currently
the reassuring thing here was that we
didn't end up ordering
a ton more echocardiograms so if we had
because clinicians were given the
results and they could integrate that
with their clinical gestalt
and order an echo if they thought it was
valuable so we don't think
that deploying this technology is likely
to increase healthcare costs
all that much and and we're likely to
pick up a lot of new cases
you can see that the model performed
particularly well in the outpatient
clinic which gives us some clues about
how this could be deployed
and it may be particularly valuable in
patients who are not in the hospital
because if you're in the hospital echoes
are relatively uh accessible
and we probably are not missing nearly
as many cases there but in the
outpatient setting
it can be hard to know who to work up
and who to refer to cardiology and so
forth
and in those patients these kinds of
technologies may improve our clinical
care
once we diagnosed a low ejection
fraction in the study 97 percent of
people in the intervention arm were
appropriately treated with
ace inhibitors or beta blockers these
are the drugs that are proven
to improve outcomes in these patients so
not only were we making a difference
with diagnosis
but we were getting patients on the
treatments that they needed
looking at this another way for every
thousand patients that we make this kind
of ai technology available to
we will pick up about five new cases of
previously unrecognized and
potentially dangerous low ejection
fraction now that may not seem like a
lot
but at a health cent at a health system
like mayo clinic where we do 400 000
ecgs
very easily we could pick up hundreds if
not a couple thousand patients a year
who otherwise would have slipped through
the cracks and eluded diagnosis of low
ejection fraction
so i think very encouraging that these
kinds of technologies could be deployed
at low cost and at scale to the benefit
of our patients
the next study that i'll mention is uh
evaluation of patients with
atrial fibrillation and the logical
extension of creating an algorithm that
can pick up afib risk
is that maybe we should be employ
deploying this in order to screen
but current guidelines actually don't
recommend screening with an ecg
and the reason is diagnostic yield is
relatively low because their arrhythmia
can be fleeting
and we don't really know how to treat
screen detected atrial fibrillation so
we'd like to try to
build out our evidence base around this
these kinds of questions
so this next study the first was eagle
the second is beagle uh
sort of cutely named but it's our sort
of the next test the next
trial along the uh uh
sort of life cycle of evaluation of
these algorithms
what we're doing is using structured and
unstructured data from the electronic
electronic health record
to identify patients in whom af
screening would be valuable
so if we were to diagnose atrial
fibrillation
they would be at sufficient risk of
stroke because they have other risk
factors that we would actually want to
anticoagulate them
so we first start by identifying the key
patients we then apply the ai algorithm
to any existing ecg that's already been
done on that patient
so we're not even asking them to come in
for an additional ecg
most of these patients at high risk have
had an ecg for one reason or another
we apply that ai to retrospective data
and identify patients who we think are
at risk of atrial fibrillation and then
send them
a cardiac monitor that they can wear for
30 days to make a definitive diagnosis
the monitor looks like this and one of
the first patients that we hooked up was
a retired
mayo clinic doctor who had diabetes and
hypertension and chronic kidney disease
so we
we wanted to know if he had atrial
fibrillation if you look at his model
output over the years
for for a decade he's looked like he's
been at high risk of atrial fibrillation
but every ecg and he had had over 30
ecgs at mayo showed normal sinus rhythm
but shortly after we picked up uh and
hooked up the
monitor he actually went into atrial
fibrillation we called him up
put him on a blood thinner and he's
getting the treatment he needs and
hopefully this patient
we've reduced his risk of stroke and
maybe even prevented a stroke
stat news actually just recently
profiled this and they found another
patient from our trial this was a
another retired mayo clinic
finance executive who enrolled in the
trial
he had always been in sinus rhythm but
it had some palpitations he looked like
he was high risk
we sent them the monitor and indeed he
was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation
and if you want to read more about this
you can read the stat article by casey
ross and i think it gives a very
balanced
look at the upside and the potential
downside of these kinds of technologies
and the feasibility of rolling them out
at scale
in addition to doing these sorts of
clinical trials we want to find novel
ways to get these algorithms to the
point of care
and we've created a dashboard within our
electronic health record so this is my
de-identified database i've had one ecg
and you can see that it it could tell
that i was male
it doesn't think i have atrial
fibrillation it doesn't think i have
hypertrophy cardiomyopathy or low
ejection fraction
and it got my age more or less correct
so this is now available to mayo clinic
clinicians and they can look at these
kinds of data and start to explore it
with the patient and figure out how
these things might be applied
while we work towards it so it's there
at a point
a single click within epic and it'll
pull up this dashboard
my data wasn't all that interesting but
there are other cases like this patient
who had had
heart failure in the early 2000s he then
had a heart
transplant and his uh ai for e ab normal
ejection fraction actually normalized he
did well until he came back
at the end of last year with a rejection
of his transplanted heart and the ai
actually picked that up
so we think about maybe we could screen
patients for transplant rejection with
those kinds of technology
and there's lots of very interesting
things that we're going to start to work
to
test going forward we were working
for quite some time with a company that
makes this very interesting stethoscope
that contains these two
metal plates and because of these two
metal plates it can record a single lead
ecg that's displayed on a smartphone
and we found that we can actually deploy
the ai algorithm
on that single lead ecg and then use the
uh used a stethoscope to actually detect
the likelihood of low ejection fraction
and this is a technology that's under
development and we're
enthusiastic about the capability of
deploying these algorithms with the sort
of edge computing
approaches at the point of care so i
think what you can see is that
we've known for a long time in medicine
that we provide
the best patient care when we leverage
multiple specialties
and we all work together around the
needs of the patient
but what you can see is that there's
probably a role for the ai
engineer the computer scientists the
data scientists
in direct patient care and we now work
very closely with
our engineering team and they've helped
us look at some old problems in new ways
and i think are really helping us
provide better care at mayo clinic
so i think you can see that there's
clinical utility i think you're seeing
that we can predict
and detect disease that these kinds of

and that by working uh together we're
able to drive uh
practice innovation and it's been very
